description: Visual representation of Ameca, initially located in the Archdiocese of Mexico (now under the Diocese of Guadalajara). Created by an unknown artist, the map depicts the administrative capital of Ameca and the surrounding communities and landscape. Centered on the map is the Pueblo de Ameca with its principal church, plaza, jail, and royal houses. Surrounding the plaza and central buildings are the houses of the town of Ameca. A river with various branches is seen throughout the map as well as two ranges of mountains that mark the left and right of the map. The main roads are marked and labeled, reaching outlying cities like Ixcatlan, Guadalajara, las minas de Guachingo, minas de Palmarejo, Mexico, and the province of Avalos. There are a good number of farms and properties shown and corresponding labels of their owners. Some of these include the different wheat farms of Juan Sanchez, Juan Vazquez, Juan Nunez, and Francisco de Mesa. Other farms of livestock include the sheep farms of Uergara, Martin Jurado, and Nuno de Lemos. A few smaller towns depicted include Jayamitlan and Huitzquilic. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Ameca.@en

description: Visual representation of Cuzcatlan, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map depicts the administrative capital of Cuzcatlan and the surrounding communities and landscape. The principal church and fountain of Cuzcatlan are seen in the upper center of the map. Roads and footpaths lead to the outlying communities that fall within the Cuzcatlan jurisdiction. The towns are represented by either a church or a traditional house and include San Francisco Istlaman (Xitlaman) (S Franco Istlaman (Xitlaman)), Santa María Jujutla (Sta Mra Jujutla), San Martín Mazateopan (S Mín Mazateopan), San Joseph Petlapan (S Joseph Petlapan), Santiago Tilapa (Stiago Tilapa), Santa María Calipan (Sta María Calipan), San Mateo Tlacuchcalco (S Mateo Tlacuchcalco), San Antonio Comulco (S Anto Comulco), San Pedro Otontepetl (S Po Otontepetl), a church without a label, thought to be San Juan Ajusco, and San Jerónimo Asuchitlan. Irrigated fields near prominent rivers are seen throughout the map along with squares representing salt production on the lower half of the map. Toponyms and glyphs are also seen throughout the map. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Cuzcatlan.@en

description: Visual representation of Cholula, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by an unknown artist, the map depicts the administrative capital of Cholula and the surrounding six principal neighborhoods of Cholula. The map is laid out in a grid like fashion with each community represented in a quadrant. The city center of San Gabriel de Cholula is seen in the middle of the map and includes the convent, chapel, and church of San Gabriel, the main plaza, fountain, and marketplace. Each of the six neighborhoods is labeled and depicted with its church and a representative image of a mountain. The rest of the map shows the streets connecting the different neighborhoods and depictions of the houses and other buildings of each area. The six neighborhoods are San Miguel Tecpan, Santiago, San Juan, Santa María, San Pablo, and San Andrés. The principal roads are visible, leading to outlying cities like Mexico City, Huexotzingo (Huejotzingo), and Los Ángeles (Puebla). Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Cholula.@en

description: Visual representation of Atengo and Misquihuala, towns in the archbishopric of Mexico. Created by a local, Indigenous artist, the map illustrates the positioning and boundaries between Santa María de Atengo, Misquiahuala, and Tesontepeque. Outlying, smaller communities are also depicted as well as the landscape and geographical features of the region. Other communities shown are Tecapatepeque, Tula, and Tepeitic (Tepeiti) and the properties listed include Juan de Cabrera, Martín Cerón, and Jerónimo López (Jrmo Lópz). description: Visual representation of Cempoala and its surroundings, located within the Archdiocese of Mexico. Cempoala is also known by the indigenous name of Campoli. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map features dozens of toponyms, and dozens of glyphs with identifying captions representing natural resources, animals, churches, and other places throughout the depicted region. The map also features thirteen named human figures, representing both Spanish and indigenous people. Featured prominently on the map is the glyph for Campoli, the altepetl, or city-state, of the region. The glyph is of a large hill topped with the drawing of a head of a Totonac (indigenous group of Campoli). Other items to note include the Acueducto del Padre Tembleque and its route that leads to the main church Todos Santos in Campoli, the human figures that are identified and typically associated with a smaller town within the region, and the numerous glyphs that signify the natural resources, animals, and other items of note within the region. Created in response to question ten listed within the relaciones geográficas questionnaire for Cempoala.@en

description: Visual representation of Atlatlauhca, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. The map, created by an unknown artist, depicts the administrative capital of Atlatlauhca and the surrounding communities and landscape. The town of Atlatlauhca is seen at the center of the map with its principal church and a few houses. Two large mountains dotted with trees bookend the town, one being identified as Monte de Atlatlauhca. The region water source is just above the town and the map shows the direction of its flow. Footpaths and roads connect Atlatlauhca to the smaller surrounding communities including Suchiaca (and its mountain), Tenantzinco, Teutenango, Calimaya y Tepemaxalco, and Toluca. The map also includes the two towns of San Pedro (San Po) Cihuatepeque (Cihutepeq) and Epayauhtlan (Epayautla), which are subjects of Tacuba. Also shown is the town of Maxteca, which is a subject of Tenango. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Atlatlauhca.@en

description: Visual representation of the Coatzacualco River and the towns on its banks, located in the province of Coatzacualco in the Diocese of Oaxaca. Drawn by Francisco Stroza Gali, the map covers the full course of the river from the Gulf of Mexico to Utatepeque, which is in the province of Teguantepeque. The depths of the water are calculated at the mouth of the river along the coast and there is detail of the towns closest to the Gulf along with some detail of the coastal features including a lake and mountains. The rest of the map is essentially the course of the river with details including the curves, other smaller branches of the river, and dozens sections of rapids. A few other towns are noted but the map focuses on the river and its course. The towns included are Xaltepeque and Utatepeque. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Coatzacualco.@en

description: Visual representation of Epazoyuca, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by an unknown artist, the map lays out the streets of Epazoyuca in a grid like fashion with the town plaza and church in the center. Most of the other buildings depicted are nondescript dwellings and the streets are also unlabeled. There are several larger roads that are noted with drawn footprints signifying they are more well traveled and connect Epazoyuca with the surrounding areas. At the top of the map is the depiction of a large mountain (Tláloc) which contains the water source for Epazoyuca. The mountain's slopes are adorned with local vegetation including cactus and mazote. At the bottom of the map are rows of irrigated crops. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Epazoyuca@en

description: Visual representation of Huaxtepeque and its surroundings, located within the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by an unknown artist, the map illustrates the local rivers, water sources, vegetation, and the roads connecting the economic and political center of Huaxtepeque to the surrounding communities. Huaxtepeque is centered prominently on the map with a rendering of the Dominican convent and a glyph of a lead tree signifying Huaxtepeque as the altepetl or city-state of the region. Other smaller towns depicted on the map include Teteltzingo, Tetzhuac, Tzacapalco, Ichcatepec, Cocoyoc, and Ayahualco. Other items of note include a glyph representing the local tianguis or market and in the bottom right of the map is a garden of suchinacaztles, a flowering plant. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Huaxtepeque.@en

description: Visual representation of Teozacoalco, located in the Diocese of Oaxaca. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map depicts the Teozacoalco region both geographically and historically. The geographical representation of the area is seen towards the center right of the map in the form of a circle. The border of this circle is the limit of the jurisdiction of Teozacoalco. There are 44 glyphs on the outer boundary representing the communities found in this realm. The city of Teozacoalco is visible in the left middle of the circle with its church and plaza. A caption identifies the city as well as a description of the central houses as "Estas son las casas de don Felipe y de don Francisco su hijo, señores naturales de este pueblo." The geographical representation of the area is dotted with rivers, roads, and mountain ranges. Glyphs of animals and prominent mountains are visible. There are sixteen towns identified with either a church-like structure or a toponym and a corresponding caption listing the towns names in both Spanish and Mixteca. Some of the towns depicted include San Miguel (Cunama), San Felipe (Nundaya), Santa Cruz (Yuhuyuhua), Santo Tomás (Yutaniño), and others, each including the distance in leagues to the administrative capital of San Pedro Teozacoalco. The left part of the map is a historical genealogy of the people of the region. The left two columns are outside of the geographical circle while the third column is laid within the geography, connecting the two parts of the manuscript. The genealogy depicts the marriages or unions between members of the region over generations. According to scholar René Acuña, the genealogy represents the unions from AD 972 through 1580, the year the map was created. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Teozacoalco y Amoltepec.@en

description: Visual representation of Santiago Atitlan, located in the Diocese of Guatemala. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map depicts the administrative capital Santiago Atitlan and its surrounding communities that dot the shores of Lake Atitlan. The estancias of San Bartolomé, San Andrés and San Francisco are not depicted in this rendering. The lake and surrounding volcanoes are featured most prominently on the map. The town of Santiago is shown prominently near the middle-right of the map with its government buildings and church labeled and centered around the town plaza. People are depicted traveling by boat on the lake; birds and fish are also shown. The currents and waves of the lake are depicted along with different islands and rock outcroppings along the shoreline. Three volcanoes are drawn and labeled as Volcán Oriente (Volcán Atitlán), Volcán Fuego, and Volcán de Poniente (Volcán San Pedro). description: Visual representation of Teguantepec, located in the Diocese of Oaxaca. Created by an unknown Indigenous artist, the map depicts Teguantepec and its surrounding communities and geographical features. Teguantepec, with its church and houses, is seen in the lower middle of the map on the banks of a prominent river. The Mar del Sur or Pacific Ocean is seen on the entire right side of the map. Prominent geographical features include multiple rivers, lakes, salt flats, and multiple mountain ranges. The map depicts many neighboring towns that fall within the jurisdiction including Xalapa, Tepeguazontlan, Suchitlan San Vicente, Camotlan, Amatitlan, and about two dozen others. Other items of note include "Las salinas de don Felipe Cortés," which are shown along the coast, the roads connecting the various communities including the principal roads of Camino real de Chiapa and Camino real de Socunusco y Guatemala. Some of the mountains and ranges are labeled including Cerro del Tigre which is right next to Teguantepec and features a glyph of a tiger. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Teguantepec.@en

description: Description of Hueytlalpa as well as full descriptions of the surrounding towns located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Surrounding towns include Zacatlan, Xuxupango, Matlatlan y Chila, Papantla, Tecolutla, and Tenanpulco y Matlactonatico. Census was signed by Juan de Carrión. Document lists Mexicana and Totonaco as the languages spoken, fauna, etymology of place names, and topographic features of the land such as rivers and roads.  Descriptions place these communities in a historical, geographical, and cultural context within the larger province of Zacatlan and provides details on native population, and systems of governance.  Also included are multiple visual representations of the landscape, known as pinturas or maps. This is one of a series of responses to a political and cultural survey circulated by King Philip II of Spain titled relaciones geográficas, which were gathered between the years 1579-1585.@en

description: Description of the provincial capital of Meztitlan and its surroundings, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Responses describe the history of the community, the division of surrounding provinces and their respective government officials, and the land itself listing native species of flora and fauna. Also included is an extensive description of the religious orders in the area with the most active being the Order of Saint Augustine.  A description of the topographic features of the land is included along with a description of the rivers and other water sources. The smaller towns located in province are also described, which include Xelitla, Fuerte de Xalpa, Chicontepec, Guaxulla, Llamaltlan, Chapulhuacan, Tlanchinolticpac, Yagualíca, Hueyacocotlan, Molango, Suchicoatlan, Tzaqualtipan, and Malila. At the start of the manuscript is an illustration depicting the method of recording time in the Aztec calendar. Also included is a visual representation of the landscape, known as a pintura or map. This is one of a series of responses to a political and cultural survey circulated by King Philip II of Spain titled relaciones geográficas, which were gathered between the years 1579-1585.@en

description: 17th century copy of a description of Texcoco, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Author of the original, lost 1582 work is Juan Bautista de Pomar. This copy was created by Fernando de Alva Ixtlilxóchitl, a chronicler of indigenous Aztec history. Document lists Chichimeca, Mexicana, and Otomí as the spoken languages, surrounding towns such as Chiauhtlacae, Tetzoyucan, and Cohuatlichancomo, topographic features, medicines used, and flora and fauna. Also mentioned are descriptions of the local jurisdiction, hierarchy, systems of governance, etymology of names, and architecture. This is a 17th century copy of one of a series of responses to a political and cultural survey circulated by King Philip II of Spain titled relaciones geográficas, which were gathered between the years 1579-1585. This copy is one of two existing copies of Pomar's Relación de Texcoco, with the other also being held by this repository. It is a 19th century copy titled "Relación de la Ciudad de Tezcoco" and is cataloged as JGI XII-16.@en

description: 19th century copy of a description of Texcoco, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Signer of the original 1582 work is Juan Bautista de Pomar. Document lists Chichimeca, Mexicana, and Otomí as the spoken languages, surrounding towns such as Chiauhtlacae, Tetzoyucan, and Cohuatlichancomo, topographic features, medicines used, and flora and fauna. Also mentioned are descriptions of the local jurisdiction, hierarchy, systems of governance, etymology of names, and architecture. This is a copy of one of a series of responses to a political and cultural survey circulated by King Philip II of Spain titled relaciones geográficas, which were gathered between the years 1579-1585. This 19th century copy is one of two existing copies of Pomar's Relación de Texcoco, with the other also being found in this repository. It is a 17th century copy titled "Relación de Tezcuco" and is classified as García MSS 58-57. Bibliophile Ignacio Rayón along with the collector Joaquín García Icazbalceta, utilized the 17th century copy, which at the time was located at the library of the Colegio de San Gregorio in Mexico City, to create this 19th century copy.@en
